note.body:
I finally solved the problem by setting the following link:

**sudo ln -Ts /usr/local/lib/libsane.so.1 /usr/lib64/libsane.so.1**

The reason is that my development version of SANE libraries is installed in /usr/local/lib/ while simple-scan as well as xsane search those libraries in /usr/lib64

(the command ldd /usr/bin/simple-scan was very helpful for finding out which dependencies are required)

My boot script is public on my page:
  http://boot.salstar.sk/gparted.ipxe
Uses memdisk to boot whole gparted. I can't use my own PXE settings for boot.salstar.sk, it uses original images to allow anybody to check for image originality.

You can try to boot this, if you have any virtualisation, preferable kvm.
Here are commands:

```
wget http://boot.salstar.sk/ipxe/ipxe.iso
qemu-kvm -m 2048 -cdrom ipxe.iso
```

Then press "x" key to select all OS distributions and then press "g" to boot gparted. Then just select latest version and continue to boot until you get gparted graphical desktop (not possible in 0.33).
You also can try version 0.30, which works fine.

Hmm, this method requires to have unofficial files available online, also an tftp server. My project "boot.salstar.sk" uses original files from sourceforge, not a modified ones, so I can't use this method. I am booting original iso file using memdisk or sanboot in ipxe.

events.target_title: Unable to find a medium containing live filesystem.

note.body:
Thank you. Steps to reproduce are in my 2nd post.
Attaching screenshot.
![f](/uploads/c81dfde3f65e54bbd16ab64061d8a325/f.jpg)

Here is my simplified ipxe script:

```
#!ipxe
set ver 1.0.0-1
#set ver 0.30.0-1
imgtrust --allow
imgfree
kernel memdisk iso raw
initrd http://downloads.sourceforge.net/gparted/gparted-live-stable/${ver}/gparted-live-${ver}-amd64.iso
boot
```

You can try to change from version 1.0 to 0.30, which will make it working.

And some reasons, why I can't use your pxe bootind:

boot.salstar.sk is a free/opensource/public site. It is possible to boot multiple OS without having a special setup on client side or special firewall permissions. Only http/https protocols are used to boot any OS (including gparted 0.30.0). It's only a simple script. Some OS are downloaded from public but not official mirrors, but still there are only public images downloaded, nothing specially created by me (unpacked iso and similar).

I can't add booting from tftp/nfs, because these protocols are mostly blocked on firewalls and also I need to create additional services for it. Also users can't simply verify modified content.

push_data.commit_title: SoupSession/SoupConnection/SoupSocket: Emit accept-certificate signal.
SoupSession/SoupConnection/SoupSocket: Emit accept-certificate signal.

events.target_title: SoupSession/SoupConnection/SoupSocket: Emit accept-certificate signal.

note.body: I'm using it because the default return value for accept-certificate should be TRUE (to keep it consistent with GTlsConnection's accept-certificate behavior). This means that if ssl-strict is set to FALSE, by default all certificates are accepted, unless the application implements custom certificate checking and explicitly rejects it. `g_signal_emit` always resets the return value to 0 (FALSE) in the case of no signal handler being connected.

events.target_title: SoupSession/SoupConnection/SoupSocket: Emit accept-certificate signal.

note.body: I will update my merge request to fix this, as well as the "Since" documentation tag

events.target_title: SoupSession/SoupConnection/SoupSocket: Emit accept-certificate signal.

note.body:
Well, I created this merge request because I could not figure out how to properly do this. The steps you outlined either need to be documented, but they seem rather cumbersome and error-prone to implement. The only libsoup documentation I found was this:

>  If you set “ssl-strict” to FALSE, then all certificates will be accepted, and you will need to call soup_message_get_https_status() to distinguish valid from invalid certificates. (This can be used, eg, if you want to accept invalid certificates after giving some sort of warning.)

And this certainly seems like insecure, and too late, as from my understanding this happens after the message was already transmitted over a potentially insecure connection. This seems like bad advice that should be - at a minimum - replaced with the steps you outlined. Or, add this new `accept-certificate` signal, which seems like a small price to pay (in terms of overhead) and be a lot easier to implement/use.

events.target_title: Can Gnome team please implement type-ahead-find to nautilus? We are suffering!

note.body:
Replying here since the other issue was locked.

> We don’t need more of the same issue reported

Apparently you do, since you keep missing the point. The point is that we **do NOT want or need** to search without explicitly doing so by pressing Ctrl + F. The search feature is **not** a replacement for typeahead, which you keep saying everywhere as if it were a fact. This has nothing to do with the search feature being good or bad, in fact it has nothing to do with search at all since we **don't** want to search when typing the exact first few characters of a filename!!

The reason why people keep on posting non-technical/unproductive comments about this is that you haven't even acknowledged you understand this! You keep on thinking (or at least saying) that this would be fixed by making the search faster or more relevant. I assure you that this will not be the case even if search would be instantaneous, because these are two entirely different features.

And how are we supposed to take you seriously and keep discussion civil if you say shit like

> Please use the amazing non-type-ahead search feature in GitLab

This just makes it seem like you think this is all a joke, and further proves that you don't understand what this issue is about. The GitLab search is non-type-ahead and that's great, just like the Nautilus search should stay non-type-ahead. But does GitLab start searching whenever you press any key? No, just like Nautilus shouldn't. Instead it should do what all sane file managers do and simply jump to the relevant file in the current view.

Look, I'm an open-source maintainer myself and know full well how annoying these kind of comments are. But I feel like this is necessary to help you understand what the issue is really about, and how badly everyone wants/needs it. Personally, I would already be satisfied if you acknowledged that search doesn't cover this use case but you don't want to put resources into developing and maintaining it. I just want to hear *something* from you that tells me you do understand the issue at hand.

events.target_title: GIMP crashes when opening file

note.body:
Hi Andre,

I think you need to understand how a distribution works: It tries to get
hundreds, if not thounds of software packages
to work stable along each other. This means you cannot always use the
"latest greatest" package version, even though
suse gives this approach a try with its "Tumbleweed", which is a real
desaster if you actually want to use a stable
system. I just changed from a short but painful excursion to Tumbleweed
back to Leap 15.0.

That doesn't mean I'd consider your stable version actually being
unstable, but it does mean that installing that version
to a distribution it hasn't been aligned with in combination with being
forced to use a foreign package manager (due
to lack of one of the most widespread packing formats) is nothing I
could ever recommend on an installation that is
meant to be anything but a testbed.

What I'd recommend to the gimp project is to provide other packaging
formats. I'd be willing to risk a temporary
messed up installation, but only if I could be sure I can roll back to
what was working before (without having to take
disk images).

Best regs,

     Robert

events.target_title: GIMP crashes when opening file

note.body:
Hi Jehan,

just uploaded a sample image, but the problem is reproducible with
different formats (tiff, png, pnm) from
different sources (xsane, gimp). To me it looks like some pointer,
struct offset or format (size_t being 64bit
here and 32bit there, maybe?) problem when trying to determine the
bitmap size for dynamic allocation. As
I mentioned in the report, the allocation size is not only obviously
wrong due to its size, but also changes
on consecutive attempts with identical images.

Best regs,

     Robert

events.target_title: Separate menus for top right corner

note.body:
Hello, just my humble opinion:

I don't believe this is generally a good idea as the beauty of Gnome Shell is the attempt to assemble all controls in one place.  
Separating Bluetooth (or any other) switch shatters UI.  
Users now do not need to concentrate on aiming at certain pixels on the panel. Instead they can swift to top-right corner aimlessly and choose their action later.

> Having a separate volume menu is a good way of exposing per program volume sliders. This is very cumbersome in the current UI. It also makes it quicker to switch input and output devices (great when your computer is connected to a TV).  

Enabling per-app volume control is actually good idea on condition it's all grouped under top-right menu (expandable with a click).

> By grouping network features to a single menu it becomes easier to Switch wireless networks. For people with separate SSIDs for 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz band it makes it way easier to force the device back on the 5 GHz network when it has switched. This menu could also include VPNs and I think with WireGuard on the uprising this will be a very convenient feature in the future.

Grouping networks under one menu hinders the possibility of viewing the network status of each type with single glance (like in Android's drawer with icon for each type - WiFi, Bluetooth, Carrier).

> A separate bluetooth menu allows me as a user to directly see and manage all connected devices with a single click.

This recurs to what I said in the beginning - shattered UI, need to aim with pointer. However, if the list of available BT devices was grouped under expandable list in top-right menu, it would be awesome.

To extend the idea, I'd even add Removable Drives (optional addon, I know) under top-right menu and make the entire menu ~~hover~~corner-activated like Activities.

Thank you for your time.

events.target_title: GIMP crashed when user closed a second application window
GNOME Shell becomes extremely slow and consumes tons of CPU

note.body:
I've also the same issue from F28 and F29. It always slows down after being in the lock screen after a while. For me though it seems to do it depending on the type of monitor I'm using. We have some Philips Meridian 247E3LPH Monitors that have a sensor to turn on when it detects motion. 

If I have two monitors connected when locked(the other monitor doesn't have to be the same type of monitor) the screen wakes after 5 or 10 seconds of it going black and repeatedly wakes and sleeps. If it's the only monitor hooked up it doesn't do that but both results in a slow-down and I must restart the shell. (I'm using x-org but it happens in Wayland as well)

The other monitors we use don't cause this issue. (BenQ GW2280 22-inch) I'm thinking it's because of the sensor but it's honestly just a wild guess. Hopefully that helps with debugging this issue.

events.target_title: PXE boot live filesystem Issue

note.body:
Thanks for your feedback. This issue is due to a bug in live-boot:
https://salsa.debian.org/stevenshiau-guest/live-boot/commit/8d0b91caafaca37cde9c29fdafd93cd15118da04

I have patched live-boot, and now it should work in GParted live 1.0.0-beta1-2:

https://sourceforge.net/projects/gparted/files/gparted-live-testing/1.0.0-beta1-2/

Please give it a try and let us know the results.
Thank you very much.

Steven

events.target_title: Unable to find a medium containing live filesystem.

note.body:
This is my pxelinux config on the server:
```
label GParted-live
  MENU LABEL GParted Live 1.0.0-1-amd64 (Ramdisk)
  KERNEL GParted-live-vmlinuz
  APPEND initrd=GParted-live-initrd.img boot=live union=overlay config components quiet noswap  net.ifnames=0  nosplash noeject fetch=tftp://172.18.0.1/GParted-live-filesystem.squashfs username=user username=user

  TEXT HELP
  GParted Live 1.0.0-1-amd64 runs on RAM
  ENDTEXT`
```

events.target_title: Unable to find a medium containing live filesystem.

note.body:
The files are extracted from GParted live iso or zip file. It's OFFICIAL files.
Of course, the pxelinux config file is what you have to write. It's nothing to do with the original GParted live iso or zip file. You can refer to its syslinux/syslinux.cfg, and boot/grub/grub.cfg.
As for your iPXE way, well, if you do have a problem, please take a screenshot and show more info so that others can diagnose for you.

Steven

events.target_title: Unable to find a medium containing live filesystem.

note.body:
I used vmware ws pro 15.1.0 as the virtual machine, and used your ipxe.iso to boot it. I manually ran the command in iPXE shell, and it worked without any issue. 
Therefore I believe maybe the issue is in the Linux kernel modules included in the initramfs can not find the hardware you have.

Steven

events.target_title: Unable to find a medium containing live filesystem.

note.body:
OK, finally I was able to reproduce this issue. Apparently the mechanism to trigger /dev/mtd* device in live-boot did not always work. I have patched it:
https://salsa.debian.org/stevenshiau-guest/live-boot/commit/b3a1cb85646f363ab5c4d7b045000ef6dbf33699
and it's used in GParted live 1.0.0-2 in the testing release.
Please give it a try and let us know the results.
Thank you very much.

Steven

events.target_title: Unable to find a medium containing live filesystem.

note.body:
Great! Thanks for your confirmation.

Steven

events.target_title: gvfs-udisks2-monitor sometimes detects "Mount added" -> "Mount removed" -> "Mount added" for single mount
gvfs-udisks2-monitor sometimes detects "Mount added" -> "Mount removed" -> "Mount added" for single mount

note.body:
Would be nice if this get fixed.
Note that in practice several programs get confused by this behavior and do not work properly.

E.g. pcmanfm/lxde sometimes (but not always) shows certain mount points twice:

![settings-folder-twice](/uploads/4ec3ef017ae673125dd2e58525827af8/settings-folder-twice.png)

And the volume ejector applet (lxplug-ejecter) the Raspberry Pi folks have in Raspbian does not work either in those cases. It seems to assume after the first unmount its services are not needed, and no longer offers to "safely unplug" the device.

events.target_title: gvfs-udisks2-monitor sometimes detects "Mount added" -> "Mount removed" -> "Mount added" for single mount

note.body:
That gvfs mount->unmount->mount events appear is VERY reproducible to me under Raspbian when mounting ext4 storage that has not been umounted cleanly.
Occurs more often than not.


Although even when the events occur according to "gio mount --monitor" it does not always result in pcmanfm showing folders twice, and that there is an actual problem is therefore not always that visible.
When they appear twice it shows:

```
** (pcmanfm:705): WARNING **: 03:50:12.781: got unmount for unknown desktop item
```

Probably that part is timing specific, and a bug in pcmanfm.
Perhaps caused by that it does not act on a on_mount_removed straight away, but does that on idle later: https://github.com/livanh/pcmanfm/blob/master/src/desktop.c#L694
While it does handle added mounts straight away.

Still it would be nice if gvfs did not emit this event sequence in the first place.


Ejecter application does always fails to work when the event sequence appears.
(And since the user was unable to unmount storage cleanly, as applet does not work, it is likely to happen the next time as well...)


Recall pcmanfm is also the application responsible to do the auto-mount in the first place when a new device shows up, and it calls g_volume_mount() to do that.
Can that perhaps also cause events to be generated in addition to your udisks/mtab monitoring magic?

"backport" means I rebuilt the Debian sources for unstable on Debian stable. This is a fairly standard procedure. It's basically just the Gimp sources with a few patches and a prepackaged makefile (called rules) which does everything for you.

events.target_title: Copied filenames prefixed with `x-special/nautilus-clipboard copy file://`

note.body:
I wrote s small script (basically 2 lines) to fix the issue until we have it upstream:

Place a file in ~/.local/share/nautilus/scripts/ and add those lines:
```
#!/bin/sh

TMP_FILE="$NAUTILUS_SCRIPT_SELECTED_FILE_PATHS"
echo "$TMP_FILE" | /usr/bin/xclip
```

Then its possible to access this script in Nautilus right klick dropdown in "Scripts". If that works for you, you can add a shortcut too.

events.target_title: Gtk.StyleContext.get_property doesn't set the red and green components when returning colors

note.body:
I found the problem: when the boxed property value is translated to a Python object, the structure is not copied and the Python object uses the original GValue'd pointer to the Gdk.RGBA structure. When the actual GValue argument is cleaned, the structure is altered (deallocated?), leaving a dangling pointer in the Python object.
I have a patch for it that works for me, although I'm not sure this is the way it should be fixed (maybe a pygobject guru may check it). It also fixes the font property problem above. Please find the patch below.

[pygobject-3.34.0-issue119.patch](/uploads/acbca52756d439c88b4ac3586a3bd213/pygobject-3.34.0-issue119.patch)

events.target_title: Fix issue #119
Fix issue #119

note.body: As noted in the commit comment, the Glib boxed structure is destroyed before returning to the Python calling program, leaving a dangling pointer to it. Having red and green components of an RGBA set to 0 is the result of freeing the structure (they were initially OK). By copying the structure, the problem disappears.

events.target_title: New unlock/login design

note.body:
First, I have to say the new design looks beautiful! :smiley: 

Now, there is an issue with the previous design that I am not sure if you properly addressed yet. It was already stated by @calumlind ten months ago:

> If I wake up my laptop and have no lock then return me to my desktop 

In other words, this screen shield breaks a common use case you didn't consider properly: having the automatic screen locking disabled (Settings > Privacy > Screen Lock = OFF) and yet having automatic blank screen (Settings > Power > Blank screen = 5 minutes). Why do users have to suffer the extra friction of dismissing this screen, instead of seeing their desktop immediately as desired? It doesn't provide any extra security, nor any information not available already in the desktop itself. On the other hand it is significantly slower than not having it, and no mater how beautiful it is, the feeling it produces to users in this scenario is frustration for the gratuitous annoyance.

So, will this new screen shield, now integrated with the lock screen, still show up after the screen goes blank without automatic lock?

Kernel:         x86_64 Linux 5.0.6-arch1-1-ARCH

Related proposal for https://www.gimp.org/downloads/ : as flatpak is new and gimp may well be the first time many users experience it, it might be nice to pre-empt some issues users are likely to have. Immediate disclaimer: gimp isn't flatpak, sort your own problems etc. But if users are all going to smash into the same issues and that can be helped with a few lines of text and a couple of links that might be nice right? Thus:
[all from xubuntu 18.10 perspective, MYYV]

1. flatpak install doesn't overwrite existing gimp install. Solution: 1 line of text beforehand instructing users to remove existing gimp with 'sudo apt remove' or similar.

2. flatpak doesn't auto update like 'sudo apt update' does via software centre etc. Solution: possibly add a cron job? Likely to be the same text for many people, could include the script line or link to a post. Haven't solved this myself, just realising it.

note.body:
No I don't think Lilypond uses Type 1 fonts.

The reports of blank PDF's are not quite right. What usually happens is the _first page_ is blank, and the rest is garbage. Since lots of sheet music is designed to fit on one page, lots of people are only running into the "blank" scenario. It turns out the "blank first page" is usually caused by headers ... which have text in them. Text means fonts. So anybody with a title at the top of their music pages was getting blanks. It's possible to get output on the first page by using an nil header and making sure music is the first thing you output. In that case the output will eventually end up being garbage after somewhere a text item gets stuffed in.

python-fu console not working on MacOS Mojave GIMP 2.10.10
python-fu console not working on MacOS Mojave GIMP 2.10.10

note.body:
Thanks @samm-git and  @lillolollo, this fixed the problem.  Due to your help, especially the idea that gtk is installed in multiple locations and so I don't need really need homebrew's version, at first I did

```bash
sudo mv /usr/local /usr/dodge_local
```

to make sure that no homebrew-installed things could possibly be picked up by the GIMP.
Then GIMP could bring up the Python-Fu console successfully!

Of course, the problem with this solution is, I have all kinds of things that are important to me installed via homebrew, and for some reason the GIMP was picking up python libraries from /usr/local i.e. the homebrew installed stuff, for instance, even within the now-working Python console it was saying

```ipython
>>> import sys
>>> sys.path
['/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gtk-2.0',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/gimp/2.0/plug-ins',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/gimp/2.0/python',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python27.zip',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/plat-darwin',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/plat-mac',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/plat-mac/lib-scriptpackages',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/lib-tk',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/lib-old',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/lib-dynload',
'/Users/darrenrhea/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages',
'/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages',
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/site-packages']
```

Most of this looks great because it starts with `/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/`, but that /usr/local/lib/python2.7 path does not feel right. 

It would turn out that someone (probably me following the directions given by homebrew after installing opencv?) created the following file:

`~/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/homebrew.pth`

with the contents

```python
import site; site.addsitedir("/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages")
```

and simply removing this file fixes the issue without hurting my homebrew functionality.
Vice versa, putting the file back re-causes the issue.  

```bash
# I return homebrew to its original path:
sudo mv /usr/dodge_local /usr/local

# Then this alone fixes the issue without harming homebrew installations:
mv ~/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/homebrew.pth /Users/darrenrhea/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/homebrew.dodge_pth

# whereas this alone recreates the issue:
mv ~/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/homebrew.dodge_pth ~/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/homebrew.pth
```

I found in my notes that, back in the day, if you homebrew-installed opencv, it used to ask you to make that .pth file at the end of the homebrew install, so that is how that came to be.

To be sure, it is now picking up gtk from the bundled copy:

`/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gtk-2.0/gtk`

```
>>> import gtk
>>> gtk.__file__
'/Applications/GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/Resources/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gtk-2.0/gtk/__init__.pyc'
```

Thanks again,
Darren

events.target_title: Allow Selection From Multiple User-Defined Reminder Times
Allow Selection From Multiple User-Defined Reminder Times

note.body:
I think it's a potential feature, not a bug ...

 From an average, end-user viewpoint, I believe that setting the values
in the UI would be preferable - and much more visible.  Of course, if
another route is sufficiently documented, that would work as well.

That said, my impetus in this was simply a way to customize and reuse
reminder time values not included in the UI now, I'm uncertain as to
your meaning of the "type of reminder and all its parameters".

Thanks,

Ed

events.target_title: Allow Selection From Multiple User-Defined Reminder Times

note.body:
Ah, I understand your viewpoint now.

My concern is only with setting the reminder *timing*, e.g., 2 days
before, 7 days before, etc, with the other settings being as they
already are in the UI.  Now, of course, I don't know how others use this
feature and what they might expect.


Ed

events.target_title: Allow Selection From Multiple User-Defined Reminder Times

note.body:
Wonderful!

thank you

Ed

events.target_title: System properties Network > Wired settings > IPv4 missing DNS domain search list field

note.body:
There are two rather unsatisfactory workarounds I have tested on Ubuntu 18.04. One is to set the Domains variable in /etc/systemd/resolved.conf. (Assumes the use of systemd-resolved.) The other is to manually edit the "Wired connection" entry in /etc/NetworkManager/system-connections. Both of these workarounds are rather obscure and certainly not as straightforward as accessing via the control center.

This is clearly either an oversight or an intentional omission in the ip4-page.ui portion of the [gnome-control-center source](https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-control-center). If intentional, it would at least be interesting to hear the rationale for this design decision.

events.target_title: System properties Network > Wired settings > IPv4 missing DNS domain search list field

note.body:
I propose adding a "Search domain" or a "Domains" input below the DNS entry in the radio_manual section of the ip4-page.ui that would set the dns-search variable in the [ipv4] section of the NetworkManager "Wired connection" entry. 

![Screenshot_from_2019-04-12_10-24-52](/uploads/2283a6adb3c1066dbb3823c7cd5690ea/Screenshot_from_2019-04-12_10-24-52.png)

events.target_title: System properties Network > Wired settings > IPv4 missing DNS domain search list field

note.body:
[Lonnie Best](https://gitlab.gnome.org/lonniebiz) comments on the need for supporting the addition of a "additional search domains" entry is quite right. Omission of a method to define search domains breaks static (aka "manual") IPv4 functionality in many cases where hostnames are provided without the FQDN. 

Use of hostname only has been a common practice going back thirty years and even now DHCP defaults to providing the search domain, so omitting a method to enter it in static configuration is IMHO simply wrongheaded.

events.target_title: Gimp Crash Debug Window open after Save, Save new Name, Export
mouse: Add support for enabling and disabling mouse acceleration.

note.body: @feaneron @whot Incidentally, what is the rationale behind using adaptive acceleration by default? It seems to me that 1:1 pointer movement would be a much more natural choice.

events.target_title: mouse: Add support for enabling and disabling mouse acceleration.

note.body: @whot Fair enough. Just in case: by "1:1 pointer movement" I meant to refer to the flat acceleration profile (sorry for the confusion). It would be nice if you guys considered moving the profile selection to the settings, as it's too essential to be considered a "tweak".

events.target_title: Not working on 19.04

note.body: There are some extensions that don't work, such as the *Places Status Indicator*, *Workspace Indicator*, and the *Applications Menu* extensions. All of them are reported to be updated on May 8, from GNOME Software. I am not using Ubuntu 19.04, but openSUSE Tumbleweed. The issue started from the last snapshot released.

events.target_title: Not working on 19.04

note.body:
openSUSE Tumbleweed was updated to 20190507-130.1. (That is the version given for the *openSUSE-release* package.)

That, together an update of the extensions, fixed the issues I was having, including not seeing the *Activity* menu.

Now my computer is running GJS 1.56.1.

events.target_title: Not working on 19.04

note.body: In my case, the error happened right after booting openSUSE. I have not been able to use the extensions I listed earlier until openSUSE Tumbleweed was updated. I rebooted openSUSE, and all returned to the normality.

events.target_title: Not working on 19.04

note.body: As for applying the updates to the live-session, isn't restarting GNOME Shell sufficient?

Author: Michael Natterer <mitch@gimp.org>

    Issue #2794 - Gimp crash just on File Open and Edit Preferences

events.target_title: GIMP fails to start: Bus error (core dumped)
GIMP fails to start: Bus error (core dumped)

note.body:
Running `$ make config` in either of graphics/gimp meta port or graphics/gimp-app renders no option for recompile WITH_DEBUG. Both these ports `include` the standard bsd.port.mk file which is no help either. So as far as I can tell I cant help you out because the necessary options to debug The Gimp are excluded from the BSD distro. What I'm trying to say is that even if I include WITH_DEBUG_PORTS=yes in my ports wide /etc/make.conf (re-compile all gimp dependencies), then install those it would not have any effect on ports that do not render this option. Of course "all" other ports that The Gimp depends on probably would include symbols and that some debug info would spill out of the built-in Gimp tools. This however would not help because this failure looks like a mis-aligned shared memory write directly relating to internal Gimp code i.e. either script-fu or a dark-theme of some sort.
Please also note that at this time I have installed the standard rendering for graphics/gimp from FreeBSD binaries, ports, and built my own using two different methods. They ALL fail. So while I can understand and appreciate your need for debugged output, if had that option we would not be having this talk. The only thing I haven't done is built and installed from your sources. REALLY! Is that necessary.
